intro: Thaspium chapmanii, commonly known as Chapman's thaspium, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, yellowish flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is often found in arid or semi-arid environments. It has a compact growth habit and is adapted to withstand drought conditions. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and endemic species.
